awd_titl_txt: SG: The macroecology of parasites of invasive host species
awd_abstract_narration:
The distribution of plant and animal species may change due to both natural causes, or due to human-assisted introductions to new areas. This research uses a large global database that documents the occurrence of mammals and their parasites to determine the kinds of parasites that are gained and lost by different species as they are introduced to new areas. This study explores how environmental factors and the traits of parasites (how they are transmitted or whether they specialize on a host) may explain whether they are retained, lost, or newly acquired.  This study will allow researchers to anticipate new associations between parasites and host species, which is important to conservation science, public health, and the food industry. This research program will train undergraduate and graduate students and school teachers in the use of existing databases and computational software for addressing pressing ecological questions.

The goal of this study is to use the Global Mammal Parasite Database and other data sources to examine the association of mammals and their parasitic hosts following their introductions into novel geographic areas. Statistical and modeling approaches to disentangle the role of climatic similarity, phylogenetic compatibility, and parasite traits (transmission mode, level of specialization and prevalence) will be developed to explain the loss and gain of parasites by introduced mammals. This work addresses a fundamental question in community and disease ecology by exploring the factors that promote the intimate associations between species pairs. Given the geographic scope of this study and breadth of introductions examined, the results of this research will provide a global context for assessing the risk of emerging infectious diseases of animals and humans due to the redistribution of introduced hosts and their parasites.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the training of one undergraduate and two graduate students in host-parasite community ecology (i.e. interactions involving multiple host and parasite species) and macroecology (i.e. global host-parasite interactions, with very broad taxonomy, incorporating relatedness of host species, and occasionally parasite species). Additionally the students were trained in theoretical ecology and statistical modeling. 

Among the main findings, theoretical and empirical evidence was provided that supports the following:

1) Rules for parasite loss and acquisition as host species invade new communities can be established, and predict loss and acquisition with high accuracy. These rules include an interaction between the phylogenetic barrier between host species (how related they are to each other) and the degree of specificity of the parasite (the extent to which the parasite specializes on few, potentially related, host species). 

2) Parasites that exist in food webs (circulating through a community of hosts in which transmission occurs during predation) are under selection by those food webs such that the food web structure (which species eat which other species) can favor either specialist or generalist infection strategies - essentially whether that parasite effectively uses several or few host species. 

3) Viruses that exhibit phylogenetic aggregation (infection of discrete clusters of related hosts) are more likely to be zoonotic (capable of jumping into human populations). 

The research was successful in generating mechanistic explanations for parasite sharing and parasite transmission to new species. This has advantages over purely correlative studies, which are more vulnerable to incomplete and imperfect sampling and can be difficult to interpret and therefore translate to other systems. 

In publications, methods and code are made available and discussed in the context of their potential to address new questions (new parasite data, host movement under land use and climate change, and other interspecific interactions, such as plant-pollinator interactions).
